positive.review:
Thief Simulator offers an addictive, methodical gameplay loop built around scouting, stealing, and selling. Each heist feels rewarding, with solid progression as you unlock new regions, tools, and techniques. The tutorial is impressively thorough, clearly explaining each mechanic so you’re never lost or overwhelmed.

The gameplay loop is simple but satisfying—casing houses, learning resident routines, disabling alarms, and making a clean getaway. It’s repetitive in a relaxing way, perfect for a laid-back session of quiet larceny. The visual detail and day-night cycle help sell the illusion, adding both realism and tension.

For the price (around $2 on sale), it’s an easy recommendation, offering 20+ hours of engaging content and freedom to experiment with your approach.

That said, New Game+ leaves something to be desired. Progression slows dramatically when starting with no tools, and the new NPC routines make smaller houses frustratingly hard to rob without getting caught. Pedestrian AI also remains inconsistent—unbothered by you sprinting down the road with a 70-inch TV, yet furious if your car touches the sidewalk.

Despite these quirks, Thief Simulator remains an enjoyable, relaxing stealth-sandbox that nails the fantasy of being a clever, calculated thief.

– The Ember Archives

The first play through of mine was very involved, it felt like I was making just the right amount of money for each upgrade as they came, and I couldn't stop robbing people. I loved robbing from people and making it out without being caught was the best feeling, maybe I should even try it in real life... just joking.

For my second, newgame+, play through the progression was extremely slow. There is no point in small robberies when you are starting at max level, so you just need money, which you can't get because you start with no tools. The change to the attendants schedule is a fun twist for your second play through, but it really means that every person is just home all of the time, so the smaller houses are essentially impossible to rob efficiently without getting caught. And the pedestrians really don't care if you are running in the middle of the street with a 70-inch plasma flat screen TV, however, god forbid your car is on the sidewalk by 1 millimeter and then they can't walk by.

First play through is really fun running around stealing stuff, only do a second play through if you want 100%, otherwise don't.

Thief Simulator is a surprisingly fun mix of stealth, planning, and sandbox gameplay. You take on the role of a thief, sneaking into houses, stealing valuables, and selling them for profit. It feels fresh compared to typical stealth games because of its open-world structure and variety of break-in opportunities.

Pros:

Open-world neighborhoods with plenty of houses and shops to target.

Stealth mechanics are simple but satisfying.

A nice sense of progression as you upgrade tools and skills.

Freedom to plan your own approach—quiet break-ins or quick smash-and-grab jobs.

Oddly relaxing, despite being about burglary.

Cons:

Graphics and animations feel a bit dated.

Can get repetitive after a while—most heists follow a similar formula.

AI of the NPCs isn’t always convincing.

Story is minimal; it’s more about the gameplay loop.

Overall:
Thief Simulator is one of those games that doesn’t take itself too seriously but ends up being super engaging. It’s not perfect, but the freedom and creativity it gives you make it a really enjoyable sandbox stealth game. If you’ve ever wondered what it’d be like to be a sneaky burglar (without the real-world consequences), this is the game for you.

The final act of the game and the DLC lose the plot a bit, you move on to industrial areas and palatial estates that feel more like typical stealth game levels than the things that made the rest of the game special. I usually love sneaky-sneaky games, but wow—this one involved a WHOLE lot of waiting. Patience is definitely a virtue here: wait, sneak, steal, wait, escape… REPEAT!

There were some real challenges along the way, but most of the time, if you got detected, you could just hide, wait it out, and avoid getting caught. Not the worst, but it did make the pacing feel a bit slow at times.
I enjoyed most of the achievements, but here’s the kicker: I’m really glad I started playing during the Christmas season, because this game has seasonal challenges. That’s right—Christmas and Halloween achievements. So guess who had to wait until OCTOBER just to 100% the game? Yep, me. And I was not pleased. But hey—I did it!

All in all, Thief Simulator is a solid little stealth game with some fun moments, as long as you don’t mind waiting around in the shadows (a lot)!

A fun little thieving game to pass some time with.

Unfortunately, the devs seem to care more about this game than their SEQUEL, which by all rights has currently been left to rot.
